intro: Gypsophila hirsuta var. barradensis, commonly known as the woolly gypsophila, is a flowering plant belonging to the family Caryophyllaceae. It is native to the mountainous regions of Central Asia, particularly in Kazakhstan and western China. This variety is characterized by its dense, fluffy inflorescences composed of numerous small, white or pale pink flowers. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm and thrives in well-drained, sandy or rocky soils. It is often cultivated in gardens for its ornamental value and is adapted to full sun exposure.
